Award.AwardTitle: The development of forms and functions of aggression during early childhood

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Aggressive behaviors in children can be harmful and disruptive and frequently indicate risk for psychological disorders. The contributors to and consequences of aggression depend on both the form (i.e., physical versus relational) and function (i.e., initiating versus reacting) of such conduct. This project is among the first to examine early behavioral precursors to these different types of aggression among preschoolers. This study's unique contribution is to follow children's development over time to capture how different pathways lead to different types of aggression.

A multi-method study using psychophysiological and behavioral observation measures will identify the physiological and early personality features that precede and predict different types of aggression. 230 preschoolers will be assessed at three time points over a 15 month time period. The first objective is to test distinct longitudinal pathways to forms and functions of aggression, including: 1) a developmental pathway resulting from emotion dysregulation; and 2) a developmental pathway resulting from temperamental fearlessness. The second objective is to model the mediating processes through which each personality profile leads to subtypes of aggression. This project will benefit Dr. Ostrov's ethnically and racially diverse graduate and undergraduate research assistants who will be trained on valuable research skills in the psychological and developmental sciences. These formative experiences have the potential to shape the next generation of scientists. Moreover, the proposed project has the potential to impact a significant portion of children, families, and schools within society at large.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Buffalo
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was designed to test the development of different types of aggressive behavior during the early childhood years.  We found evidence for the presence and stability of physical (e.g., hitting), relational (e.g., social exclusion), proactive (i.e., planned and goal directed) and reactive (i.e., hostile and impulsive) types of aggressive behavior among 3-5-year-olds.  That is, not only are young children engaging in these behaviors that are readily detectable by observers within classrooms as well as by parents and teachers, but children's behavior during the spring of year 1 predicted their behavior during the spring of year 3.  These findings suggests that aggressive behavior stays relatively unchanged across a 12 month period when peer relationships are rapidly becoming developmentally important. We also found that we could reliably measure heart rate, the amount of sweat in chlidren's fingers, and breathing rates among our young participants. Importantly, our preliminary findings suggest that those children that are excluded by their peers and have a higher physiological reaction (i.e., more sweat on their fingertips) when viewing a 3 minute TV show depicting social exclusion engage in more relational aggression (i.e., telling friends they can't play with them). This is one of the first studies to demonstrated that the autonomic nervous system impacts relationally aggressive behavior among young children. Our preliminary findings also suggest that other subtypes of aggression (e.g., bullying) are evident among young children and that bullying (i.e., aggression with power imbalance and repetition) seems to be different from general aggressive behavior (e.g., aggression among equal status friends). Collectively, our findings have implications for clinical treatment and suggest areas of intervention. For example, addressing social thoughts or cognitions may be an effective way to reduce some types of aggressive behavior among young children and enhancing emotion regulation skills may increase positive social and emotional outcomes in young children).  In addition, we have worked to disseminate our findings to scientific and nonscientific audiences. We have presented our work at national and international professional meetings, wrote several book chapters and a book on the topic, and have begun to publish this work in peer reviewed journals.  We have worked with media outlets to share some of our initial findings. We have presented our initial findings to key stakeholders in our local community and to participating and non-participating schools. Part of this work has included trainings for teachers and early childhood professionals on the development of aggression and social-emotional development during early childhood.  Newsletters have been distributed to families and posted on our laboratory website. The PI serves on a task force to address bullying and aggression in the local community/county and the project findings have informed the direction and recommendations of this task force.  That is, despite the disproportionate prevelance rates of bullying in middle school and high school, attention is now being given to the developmental risk associated with early aggressive behavior and bullying. 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/17/2019
Modified by: Jamie M Ostrov
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project was designed to test the development of different types of aggressive behavior during the early childhood years. We found evidence for the presence and stability of physical (e.g., hitting), relational (e.g., social exclusion), proactive (i.e., planned and goal directed) and reactive (i.e., hostile and impulsive) types of aggressive behavior among 3-5-year-olds. That is, not only are young children engaging in these behaviors that are readily detectable by observers within classrooms as well as by parents and teachers, but children's behavior during the spring of year 1 predicted their behavior during the spring of year 3. These findings suggests that aggressive behavior stays relatively unchanged across a 12 month period when peer relationships are rapidly becoming developmentally important. We also found that we could reliably measure heart rate, the amount of sweat in chlidren's fingers, and breathing rates among our young participants. Importantly, our preliminary findings suggest that those children that are excluded by their peers and have a higher physiological reaction (i.e., more sweat on their fingertips) when viewing a 3 minute TV show depicting social exclusion engage in more relational aggression (i.e., telling friends they can't play with them). This is one of the first studies to demonstrated that the autonomic nervous system impacts relationally aggressive behavior among young children. Our preliminary findings also suggest that other subtypes of aggression (e.g., bullying) are evident among young children and that bullying (i.e., aggression with power imbalance and repetition) seems to be different from general aggressive behavior (e.g., aggression among equal status friends). Collectively, our findings have implications for clinical treatment and suggest areas of intervention. For example, addressing social thoughts or cognitions may be an effective way to reduce some types of aggressive behavior among young children and enhancing emotion regulation skills may increase positive social and emotional outcomes in young children). In addition, we have worked to disseminate our findings to scientific and nonscientific audiences. We have presented our work at national and international professional meetings, wrote several book chapters and a book on the topic, and have begun to publish this work in peer reviewed journals. We have worked with media outlets to share some of our initial findings. We have presented our initial findings to key stakeholders in our local community and to participating and non-participating schools. Part of this work has included trainings for teachers and early childhood professionals on the development of aggression and social-emotional development during early childhood. Newsletters have been distributed to families and posted on our laboratory website. The PI serves on a task force to address bullying and aggression in the local community/county and the project findings have informed the direction and recommendations of this task force. That is, despite the disproportionate prevelance rates of bullying in middle school and high school, attention is now being given to the developmental risk associated with early aggressive behavior and bullying.
